title: 93 Kitchen Ideas for Every Style, Budget, and Home
text: 93 Kitchen Ideas for Every Style, Budget, and Home By Kristin Hohenadel Kristin Hohenadel Kristin Hohenadel has written on design for publications including the New York Times, Interior Design, Slate, Fast Company, and the international editions of Elle Decor. Learn more about The Spruce's Editorial Process Published on 06/18/24 Close Credit: The Spruce / Christopher Lee Foto Give your kitchen a mini refresh or a transformative makeover with kitchen ideas to suit every size and style. Whether your space is large or small, modern, contemporary, farmhouse, traditional, coastal, eclectic, minimalist, or something in between, there are easy ways to upgrade your space. Redecorating your kitchen can mean choosing a new backsplash or countertops, creating a breakfast bar, refinishing cabinets, swapping out hardware, installing new lighting fixtures, or adding a kitchen island with bar seating. Or it can involve rethinking your color scheme, flooring, appliances, window treatments, paint colors, storage, layout, and decor. Check out these wide-ranging kitchen ideas for inspiration to help you elevate your space. Want more design inspiration? Sign up for our free daily newsletter for the latest decor ideas, designer tips, and more! 01 of 93 Decorate With Plants Credit: deVOL Kitchens Decorate a modern kitchen with plants to bring the outdoors inside. This black-and-white space from deVOL Kitchens mixes bold stone finishes with classic black cabinetry. An open shelf lined with plants in mismatched containers adds an energizing dose of natural greenery. Continue to 2 of 93 below 02 of 93 Tile the Kitchen Island Credit: Louis Duncan-He Designs / Eymeric Wildling Photography Give your kitchen island a modern refresh with mixed materials and color accents. Louis Duncan-He Designs clad the rounded base of this large kitchen island with vertical stack tiles in a glossy rust-colored finish for an earthy feel, and topped it with white quartz that matches the kitchen countertops and backsplash. Continue to 3 of 93 below 03 of 93 Try a Beadboard Backsplash Credit: White Arrow A full-wall beadboad backsplash will add texture to a modern farmhouse kitchen. White Arrow added character with bold blue paint to complement darker wood flooring for a rich feel. Continue to 4 of 93 below 04 of 93 Hang Boho-Style Pendants Credit: Desiree Burns Interiors Give your kitchen a Mediterranean-inspired feel with natural materials and soft colors. Desiree Burns Interiors anchored the large kitchen island with a pair of boho-style pendant lights for a nonchalant feel. Continue to 5 of 93 below 05 of 93 Install an Appliance Garage Credit: Design by Julie Rose for Velinda Hellen Design / Styled by Emily Bowser / Photo by Sara Ligorria-Tramp Keep your countertops clutter-free by adding an appliance garage to house bulkier items like blenders and stand mixers. Julie Rose for Velinda Hellen Design positioned this one just next to open countertop workspace to make it easy to move in and out. Continue to 6 of 93 below 06 of 93 Move the Sink to the Island Credit: Jessica Nelson Design / Carina Skrobecki Photography Create an efficient layout in an open-concept space by opting for a kitchen island with an integrated sink. Jessica Nelson Design chose bright brass plumbing fixtures that mimic the gold-toned accents throughout this cozy space. Continue to 7 of 93 below 07 of 93 Try Zellige Tiles Credit: Studio Peake Give your kitchen a textural feel with a mix of tiles. Studio Peake paired a backsplash wall of glossy neutral zellige tiles with a green marble kitchen island countertop and multi-colored tile flooring to create a fresh, modern feel in this London kitchen. Continue to 8 of 93 below 08 of 93 Try an All-Black Palette Credit: Louis Duncan-He Designs / Eymeric Wildling Photography Create a sleek feel with a moody all-black kitchen. Louis Duncan-He Designs updated this midcentury modern kitchen for contemporary lifestyles with an open-concept format, integrated stainless steel appliances, and a mix of dramatic black wood and stone finishes. Continue to 9 of 93 below 09 of 93 Trade White for Beige Credit: Design by Mendelson Group / Photo by Eric Piasecki If you're looking for an alternative to an all-white kitchen, go in a warmer direction by using shades of beige. Mendelson Group chose tones of beige from the wood cabinetry to the gleaming tile backlash to the stone flooring in this welcoming kitchen. Continue to 10 of 93 below 10 of 93 Lay Down a Kitchen Rug Credit: Ashley Montgomery Design Give your kitchen a cozier feel with a kitchen rug or runner. Ashley Montgomery Design layered a neutral patterned vintage-style rug over wood flooring in this traditional space, but you can pick a style that works with your decor. Continue to 11 of 93 below 11 of 93 Try Elongated Hex Tiles Credit: Gray Space Interiors Add interest to a neutral kitchen backsplash with elongated hex tiles. Gray Space Interiors added texture to this white kitchen with oversized geometric tiles filled with grout that echoes the aged brass fixtures that help to warm up the space. Continue to 12 of 93 below 12 of 93 Add a Cozy Corner Banquette Credit: Jessica Nelson Design / Carina Skrobecki Photography Add a cozy corner banquette to create a space for casual meals and a spot for friends and family to hang out while you cook. Jessica Nelson Design added built-in storage beneath this L-shaped banquette that matches the base cabinetry in this homey space. Continue to 13 of 93 below 13 of 93 Gallery Wall Credit: Studio Peake Keep your cutting board collection visible and accessible with a gallery wall that doubles as decor. Studio Peake layered cutting boards in various shapes and sizes on the wallpapered far wall of this London galley kitchen to create a cozy and functional focal point. Continue to 14 of 93 below 14 of 93 Add a Back Kitchen Credit: Kate Marker Interiors A back kitchen is a kind of supercharged pantry located off of the main kitchen that often functions as a second kitchen used for food prep or baking, equipped with a sink, oven, counterspace, and additional storage. Kate Marker Interiors chose black cabinetry, moody gray stone cabinets, medium-toned wood and gold-toned accents for this spacious back kitchen. Continue to 15 of 93 below 15 of 93 Add Vintage Decor Credit: Brexton Cole Interiors Warm up a minimalist kitchen with vintage accents. Brexton Cole Interiors softened this streamlined space with vintage-style framed art, signage, decor objects, and aged finishes. Continue to 16 of 93 below 16 of 93 Install Integrated Lighting Credit: Maydan Architects / Photo by Peter Kubilis Give a contemporary kitchen a sleek and streamlined feel with integrated lighting. Maydan Architects added LED lighting beneath the upper cabinetry in this one-wall New York City kitchen that is practical, energy-efficient, and a decorative feature of its own. Continue to 17 of 93 below 17 of 93 Add a Farmhouse Feel Credit: Emily Henderson Design / Photo By Kaitlin Green Define an L-shaped kitchen with colorful tile walls. Emily Henderson Design chose luminous light blue tiles in this blue and white kitchen, pairing it with warm wood cabinets and shiplap finishes for a farmhouse feel. Continue to 18 of 93 below 18 of 93 Accent With Red Credit: Maite Granda Energize a contemporary kitchen with bold color accents. Interior designer Maite Granda gave this coastal Florida kitchen an unexpected shot of red, but you can substitute your favorite color, from neon yellow to orange or bright green. Continue to 19 of 93 below 19 of 93 Mix Lighting Fixture Styles Credit: Alvin Wayne Mix kitchen lighting fixtures of varying styles to define individual spaces in a large kitchen. Desiree Burns Interiors took advantage of the soaring ceilings in this double-height kitchen to hang a central beaded chandelier, with a pair of industrial black metal pendant lights anchoring the peninsula seating. Continue to 20 of 93 below 20 of 93 Repaint Kitchen Cabinets Credit: Michelle Berwick Design Repaint kitchen cabinets to give your space a fresh perspective. Michelle Berwick Design paired a peachy shade on base cabinets and a scalloped range hood, complementing it with wood tones and terracotta tiles on the kitchen island. Continue to 21 of 93 below 21 of 93 Add English Cottage Style Credit: deVOL Kitchens Bring the English countryside to your kitchen with vintage lighting, a lace-edged curtain on the window over the sink, and terracotta pots filled with herbs and geraniums, like this space from deVOL Kitchens. A fresh palette of pink and green will make modern kitchens feel inviting, too. Continue to 22 of 93 below 22 of 93 Set Up an Open Pantry Credit: Velinda Hellen for Emily Henderson Design / Photo by Veronica Crawford Carve out space at the end of a kitchen island to install a mini pantry in a kitchen that doesn't have space for a walk-in pantry. In this kitchen from Velinda Hellen for Emily Henderson Design, one end of the kitchen island is lined with shelving filled with identical jars of dry goods to create an accessible mini pantry that doubles as edible decor. Continue to 23 of 93 below 23 of 93 Add a Second Kitchen Island Credit: Leclair Decor In a large kitchen, trade a massive kitchen island for double islands. Leclair Decor clad both islands in the same finishes for a unified feel, adding seating to the outer island. Continue to 24 of 93 below 24 of 93 Install a Window Shade Credit: Calimia Home While it can be tempting to leave the window over your kitchen sink bare, the right window treatment can make it more functional and attractive. Calimia Home chose a woven shade that complements warm wood and patterned tile, providing light and privacy control when needed. Continue to 25 of 93 below 25 of 93 Add a Bonus Cutting Block Credit: Erin Williamson Design Add extra prep space with a bonus butcher block countertop. Erin Williamson Design installed a freestanding butcher block table across from the sink at the end of this kitchen island that adds dedicated food prep space that avid bakers will especially appreciate. Continue to 26 of 93 below 26 of 93 Carve Out a Breakfast Nook Credit: Michelle Berwick Design In a smaller kitchen, carve out a breakfast nook in a wall of built-in cabinetry. Michelle Berwick Design added an upholstered seat and a small round table and chairs, anchoring the space with vibrant wallpaper and a modern pendant light to bring the café energy to this bright space. Continue to 27 of 93 below 27 of 93 DIY Some Reclaimed Shelving Credit: Lobster and Swan Add a rustic feel to your kitchen with reclaimed wood shelving. Lobster and Swan made budget-friendly sustainable DIY shelving for everyday objects and supplies using reclaimed wood from a number of sources, then stained it all in the same rich tone for a cohesive feel. Continue to 28 of 93 below 28 of 93 Hang Café Curtains Credit: deVOL Kitchens Give your eat-in kitchen dining nook a bistro feel with café curtains. This cozy corner banquette from deVOL Kitchens has sheer white half-curtains on a brass rod that filter light and vintage furniture to create an inviting environment for leisurely meals. Continue to 29 of 93 below 29 of 93 Decorate With Art Credit: Ashley Montgomery Design Decorate your kitchen with art to make it feel warm and inviting and not just a utilitarian space. Ashley Montgomery Design leaned a framed thrift store still life against the wall behind the countertop to add vintage vibes to a modern kitchen. Continue to 30 of 93 below 30 of 93 Install New Flooring Credit: deVOL Kitchens Your choice of kitchen flooring can have an outsized impact on your overall decor scheme. Freshen up dated floors with bright patterned tile, wood floors to match the rest of your interior, or add character with aged finishes like the rustic terracotta floor tiles in this space from deVOL Kitchens. Continue to 31 of 93 below 31 of 93 Pad Your Bar Stools Credit: Desiree Burns Interiors Upgrade your kitchen peninsula bar seating with faux fur seat covers that will make them more comfortable and decorative, like this semi open-plan apartment kitchen from Desiree Burns Interiors. Continue to 32 of 93 below 32 of 93 Choose Colorful Appliances Credit: House of G Designs / Photo by Public 311 Design Creating a colorful kitchen can be as easy as choosing an appliance in anything but a neutral shade. House of G Designs animated this earth-toned kitchen with an orange retro-style fridge from Big Chill to create a focal point. Continue to 33 of 93 below 33 of 93 Swap the Island for a Table Credit: Design by Leanne Ford Interiors / Styling by Hilary Robertson / Photo by Amy Neunsinger Swap a modern kitchen island for a traditional farmhouse table to create a cozy feel that recalls the kitchens of times past. Leanne Ford Interiors chose a dark wood table and bentwood chairs to add contrast with the creamy white walls and cabinetry. Continue to 34 of 93 below 34 of 93 Try Terrazzo Flooring Credit: Design by Hub of the House Studio / Meghan bob Photography Terrazzo flooring will give your kitchen a fun retro feel. Hub of the House Studio paired multi-colored large terrazzo flooring with moody dark green cabinets and brass accents in this midcentury modern-inspired kitchen reno. Continue to 35 of 93 below 35 of 93 Try a Small Kitchen Island Credit: Becca Interiors Make a compact kitchen more functional with a small kitchen island. Put it on wheels like this versatile piece from Becca Interiors that is painted sage green to match the base cabinetry. Continue to 36 of 93 below 36 of 93 Opt for Open Shelving Credit: Calimia Home Swap upper cabinetry for open shelving to create an airy modern feel. Calimia Home hung a pair of chunky natural wood shelves on either side of the kitchen window to keep everyday items visible and accessible. Continue to 37 of 93 below 37 of 93 Hang a Chandelier Credit: Ashley Montgomery Design Give a traditional kitchen an authentic feel with an antique chandelier. Ashley Montgomery Design hung a crystal chandelier above this massive aged copper island that complements ornate crown moldings and heavily veined stone. Continue to 38 of 93 below 38 of 93 Use a U-Shaped Layout Credit: Jessica Nelson Design / Carina Skrobecki Photography Optimize space with a U-shaped kitchen layout. Jessica Nelson Design added variation to this all-white space with mixed finishes, from the painted Shaker cabinets to the zellige tile walls and quartz countertops and range backsplash. Continue to 39 of 93 below 39 of 93 Color Drench Your Kitchen Credit: Margaret Wright Interiors Give your kitchen a current feel by color drenching the walls, window trim, and cabinetry in the same color. This rich blue kitchen has a cozy feeling that frames the view to the outside. Choose black for a more dramatic feel, or a warm shade of pink, red, or orange for an uplifting space. Continue to 40 of 93 below 40 of 93 Install a Pot Filler Credit: Marie Flanigan Interiors When renovating a kitchen, add small luxuries and modern conveniences that make it more user-friendly for avid cooks. Marie Flanigan Interiors added a brass pot filler above the range in this kitchen that doubles as decor. Continue to 41 of 93 below 41 of 93 Embed a Beverage Fridge Credit: Louis Duncan-He Designs / Eymeric Wildling Photography Upgrade an open-concept kitchen with a glass-front beverage fridge that makes it easy for everyone to grab their favorite drink. Louis Duncan-He Designs chose a sleek built-in model in this modern space. Continue to 42 of 93 below 42 of 93 Try Peel-and-Stick Credit: Tempaper & Co. For renters or those who like to change up their decor with minimal effort and investment, a peel-and-stick wallpaper or tile backsplash is an easy way to give your kitchen a mini makeover. This neutral patterned wallpaper from Tempaper & Co. can change the look of your kitchen in a flash, and removed when it's time to pack up and go. Continue to 43 of 93 below 43 of 93 Use Matching Stone Finishes Credit: deVOL Kitchens Dramatic marble adds movement, pattern, and high style to your kitchen renovation. This space from deVOL Kitchens is finished with Italian Arabescato marble on the countertops, sink, backsplash, and open shelving for a showstopping look. Shades of earthy green on cabinetry and walls and aged brass accents add balance and warmth. Continue to 44 of 93 below 44 of 93 Choose a Waterfall Island Credit: Louis Duncan-He Designs / Eymeric Wildling Photography Waterfall islands add a current feel to a modern kitchen. Louis Duncan-He Designs paired a dramatic black stone waterfall island with light wood flooring for a high-contrast feel. Continue to 45 of 93 below 45 of 93 Add a Bistro Table Credit: Calimia Home Add seating to a kitchen without an island or a peninsula by setting up a chic little space-saving bistro table and chairs instead. Calimia Home added a cozy spot for coffee breaks and quick meals in this tranquil modern kitchen decorated with marble finishes, sage green base cabinets, and warm mixed metals. Continue to 46 of 93 below 46 of 93 Add a Built-In Dining Table Credit: Kate Marker Interiors If you love your kitchen island but find chairs more comfortable than bar stools, compromise and use one side of the island to anchor a dining table and chairs. Kate Marker Interiors combined an island and a formal dining table in this luxury kitchen that's fit for family time or entertaining. Continue to 47 of 93 below 47 of 93 Set Up a Coffee Bar Credit: Emily Henderson Design / Photo by Sara Ligorria-Tramp Convert a built-in pantry into a home coffee bar to create a dedicated spot for refueling. Emily Henderson Design equipped this space with a coffee maker and supplies, installing foldaway doors that make it convenient to use when open and easy to close up when not in use. Continue to 48 of 93 below 48 of 93 Try an Induction Stovetop Credit: Charlie Interior Design Trade a bulky range with an induction cooktop for a sleeker, easier-to-clean, and more energy-efficient kitchen. Charlie Interior Design paired the induction stovetop with a modern range hood, but you can install these flat stovetops in any style kitchen. Kitchen Appliances & Products Reviews Continue to 49 of 93 below 49 of 93 Go With All-White Finishes Credit: Studio Peake You can't go wrong with an all-white kitchen in a smaller space. Mix finishes to add texture to a monochromatic space like this corner kitchen from Studio Peake. Continue to 50 of 93 below 50 of 93 Install Black Fixtures Credit: Leclair Decor Matte black plumbing fixtures will instantly modernize any kitchen. Leclair Decor paired this modern black faucet with a black undermount sink for a sleek feel, adding contrast with white quartz countertops and a matching backsplash and light wood open shelving to add warmth. Continue to 51 of 93 below 51 of 93 Paint the Kitchen Island Credit: Maite Granda Turn your kitchen island into a focal point with a simple coat of paint. Interior designer Maite Granda chose a royal blue island to add contrast in this coastal Florida kitchen. Continue to 52 of 93 below 52 of 93 Hang Large-Scale Pendants Credit: Becca Interiors Hang large-scale pendants to anchor a spacious kitchen of any style. Becca Interiors chose vintage-style glass-and-metal pendants over this massive kitchen island with rounded corners to give this transitional kitchen a dramatic but homey feel. Continue to 53 of 93 below 53 of 93 Embrace Sage Green Credit: Wee Spaces Paint your kitchen cabinets, walls, and/or island in a soothing nature-inspired shade of sage green to freshen up a neutral space. Wee Spaces paired sage green paint with plenty of white and light neutral wood, leather, and woven tones in this modern kitchen. Continue to 54 of 93 below 54 of 93 Try Modern Cottage Style Credit: Becca Interiors Create a moody take on modern cottage kitchen style with dark cabinetry and rustic wood. Becca Interiors combined blue-black cabinetry with white shiplap walls, rustic wood open shelving, and stainless steel appliances to give this homey kitchen some edge. Continue to 55 of 93 below 55 of 93 Wallpaper the Ceiling Credit: Design by Mendelson Group / Photo by Eric Piasecki Create a bold accent in a large kitchen by wallpapering the ceiling. Mendelson Group chose a green-and-white check pattern that sets the tone, and carried the kitchen color scheme throughout with a decorative plate wall and built-in island wine storage. Continue to 56 of 93 below 56 of 93 Embrace Danish Simplicity Credit: Louis Duncan-He Designs / Photo by Matt Van Emmerik Scandinavian-style kitchens are simple, functional, streamlined, and quietly chic. Louis Duncan-He Designs channeled Danish modern style in this kitchen with natural wood tones, pale stone, and an uncluttered feel. Continue to 57 of 93 below 57 of 93 Hang Corner Shelves Credit: Marie Flanigan Interiors Optimize space by hanging corner shelves. Marie Flanigan Interiors chose natural wood to complement the earth-toned zellige tile backsplash for an airy look. If you need or want more storage, install a corner cabinet instead. Continue to 58 of 93 below 58 of 93 Try a Sunny Color Palette Credit: Dazey Den While midcentury modern interiors were often neutral, they also embraced color. Dazey Den channeled the 1960s and '70s in this Palm Springs home, remodeling the kitchen with a vibrant palette of oranges and yellows for a lighthearted throwback feel. Continue to 59 of 93 below 59 of 93 Choose a Graphic Backsplash Credit: Arbor & Co. Add style to a small kitchen with a bold graphic backsplash. Arbor & Co. chose a geometric black-and-white half-circle pattern to complement dark green base cabinetry, white walls, and brass finishes. Continue to 60 of 93 below 60 of 93 Add a Home Bar Credit: White Sands Set up a home bar in an open-concept kitchen to create a dedicated spot to prepare drinks and store supplies. White Sands painted this home wet bar in a cheerful shade of pale pink and added a mirror, open shelving, and built-in beverage fridges to keep this space entertainment-ready. Continue to 61 of 93 below 61 of 93 Do a Full-Wall Backsplash Credit: Tyler Karu Design and Interiors Add color, texture, and practicality to your kitchen with a full wall tile backsplash. Tyler Karu Design and Interiors chose a moody green to complement the medium-toned wood and black countertops in this Maine kitchen. Continue to 62 of 93 below 62 of 93 Multiply Seating Options Credit: Forbes + Masters Make a smaller open-concept apartment kitchen feel more expansive with multiple seating options. Forbes + Masters paired a small round corner table with two chairs for dining with a couple of velvet and brass bar stools on the corner of a small kitchen island where you can enjoy a drink. Continue to 63 of 93 below 63 of 93 Opt for Double Wall Ovens Credit: Charlie Interior Design If you have a large family or like to batch cook, or if you are one of those people who design their kitchens around being able to pull of Thanksgiving dinner like a pro, install double wall ovens. Charlie Interior Design installed these double ovens at and just below eye level to make them user-friendly, too. Continue to 64 of 93 below 64 of 93 Add a Statement Range Hood Credit: Britt Design Studio A statement range hood will give your kitchen a focal point and a crowning touch. Britt Design Studio chose a dark range hood with brass detailing in this traditional kitchen, but you can adapt yours to complement the style of your kitchen. Continue to 65 of 93 below 65 of 93 Hang Accent Wallpaper Credit: Casa Watkins Living Kitchen wallpaper can transform your space with unexpected pattern and color. Casa Watkins Living layered open shelving over a vibrant wallpaper accent wall to provide storage and display space in this colorful and eclectic kitchen. Continue to 66 of 93 below 66 of 93 Camouflage Your Fridge Credit: Charlie Interior Design Give your kitchen a more streamlined appearance by hiding the fridge behind built-in cabinet doors. Charlie Interior Design camouflaged a large double-fridge behind doors in this black-and-white kitchen for a seamless look. Tr Continue to 67 of 93 below 67 of 93 Try Two-Tone Cabinets Credit: Ursula Carmona of Home Made By Carmona Add dimension to your kitchen with two-tone cabinetry. Blogger Ursula Carmona of Home Made By Carmona paired midnight blue base cabinets with upper white Shaker and glass-front cabinetry in this DIY kitchen makeover. Continue to 68 of 93 below 68 of 93 Try Organic Modern Style Credit: Jenn Pablo Studio Bring a modern organic feel to your kitchen with a mix of white and earth-tone finishes and clean lines, like this soothing space from Jenn Pablo Studio. Decorate with natural elements like a simple vase of tall branches to complement the look. Continue to 69 of 93 below 69 of 93 Try Patterned Tile Floors Credit: Arbor & Co. Enliven your kitchen floors with pretty patterned tile. Arbor & Co. added movement and character to this kitchen with a decorative pattern for a timeless look. Continue to 70 of 93 below 70 of 93 Set Up a Breakfast Bar Credit: deVOL Kitchens In a small kitchen, set up a breakfast bar like this space from deVOL Kitchens. Seating for two by the window and open shelving on the wall above optimizes space in this galley-style kitchen. Continue to 71 of 93 below 71 of 93 Add Cookbook Storage Nooks Credit: Velinda Hellen Design / Photo by Sara Ligorria-Tramp Break up a block of kitchen cabinetry with open nooks for storing cookbooks or displaying decorative objects, like this Maine kitchen from Tyler Karu Design and Interiors. Continue to 72 of 93 below 72 of 93 Mix Old and New Finishes Credit: Desiree Burns Interiors Mix old and new finishes to give your kitchen a timeless feel. Desiree Burns Interiors preserved the exposed dark wood ceilings and floorboards and added simple flat-front lower cabinetry, open shelving, and modern lighting for a modern rustic feel. Continue to 73 of 93 below 73 of 93 Mix Matte and Glossy Credit: White Sands Mix matte and glossy finishes to add dimension to a neutral kitchen. White Sands combined flat-front white lacquered cabinets with stained wood to give this modern kitchen a sleek feel. Continue to 74 of 93 below 74 of 93 Embrace Retro Kitsch Credit: Dazey Den If you're a lover of all that is vintage and kitsch, renovate your kitchen with retro style. Dazey Den renovated this midcentury modern kitchen with lime green cabinets and graphic kitchen countertop tile for an irreverent feel. Continue to 75 of 93 below 75 of 93 Install a Wine Chiller Credit: Michelle Boudreau Design / Photo by Lance Gerber If you're a wine lover without a basement wine cellar, install a built-in wine chiller instead. Michelle Boudreau Design chose a slim glass-front model that fits seamlessly into this midcentury modern-style kitchen. Continue to 76 of 93 below 76 of 93 Try an L-Shaped Layout Credit: Maite Granda In a rectangular kitchen and living room combo, optimize space with an L-shaped kitchen layout. Interior designer Maite Granda tucked the kitchen in the corner of this hybrid space, positioning the sofa with its back to the kitchen to create visual separation. Continue to 77 of 93 below 77 of 93 Embrace Woodgrain Credit: Brophy Interiors Give a modern kitchen a warm feel with natural wood cabinetry with visible woodgrain. Brophy Interiors paired the honey-toned wood with matching hardware and white and gray finishes for a modern rustic feel. Continue to 78 of 93 below 78 of 93 Set Up a Coffee Corner Credit: Britt Design Studio Devote a quiet corner of your kitchen to a coffee station with a small espresso machine and a cookie jar that's ready for you when you need a wake-up shot or an afternoon break, like this space from Britt Design Studio. Continue to 79 of 93 below 79 of 93 Hang Black and White Photos Credit: Brady Tolbert for Emily Henderson Design / Photo by Tessa Neustadt Decorate the walls of your kitchen with black-and-white photography, framed prints, and wall decor for a clean modern feel, like this space from Emily Henderson Design. Continue to 80 of 93 below 80 of 93 Stain Your Cabinets Blue Credit: Kate Marker Interiors Use colored stain rather than paint to define cabinetry while allowing natural woodgrain patterns to show through. Kate Marker Interiors used a navy stain on the floor-to-ceiling cabinetry in this spacious farmhouse kitchen. Continue to 81 of 93 below 81 of 93 Choose a Vintage Island Credit: Marie Flanigan Interiors Add character to a small modern farmhouse kitchen with a vintage kitchen island. Marie Flanigan Interiors chose a French butcher block table for this space decorated with sky blue base cabinets, open shelving, and rustic wide plank wood flooring. Continue to 82 of 93 below 82 of 93 Pair Pink and Red Credit: deVOL Kitchens Create a warm and romantic feel in a traditional kitchen by pairing pink and red finishes. This space from deVOL Kitchens has soft pink walls, rosy red cabinetry, black countertops, textured red backsplash tiles, and rich wood tones for a timeless country kitchen feel. Continue to 83 of 93 below 83 of 93 Paint Cabinets Black Credit: Mary Patton Design Paint the cabinets black to give a traditional kitchen a bit of edge. Mary Patton Design paired black uppers and lowers with a matching kitchen island and white walls and countertops for a crisp feel in this space accessed by a rustic brick archway. Continue to 84 of 93 below 84 of 93 Mix in Darker Wood Tones Credit: Desiree Burns Interiors Create a modern feel in an open-plan kitchen by pairing light wood floors with warmer, darker finishes on the kitchen island and dining table seating, like this space from Desiree Burns Interiors. White walls and countertops and rounded edges keep the kitchen feeling fresh and modern. Continue to 85 of 93 below 85 of 93 Define With Wainscoting Credit: Marie Flanigan Interiors Define the dining area in an eat-in kitchen with wainscoting. Marie Flanigan Interiors chose a square grid pattern painted the same white color as the walls to add subtle variation in this New York City kitchen. Continue to 86 of 93 below 86 of 93 Add Reeded Glass Doors Credit: Design by Emilie Fournet Interiors / Photo by Kasia Fiszer Swap clear glass-front cabinetry with reeded glass to add texture and a semi-opaque finish. Emilie Fournet Interiors paired reeded glass with dark green cabinetry and brass accents for a traditional feel. Continue to 87 of 93 below 87 of 93 Plant a Tree Credit: Sola Kitchens Bring the outdoors inside by planting a tree in your kitchen. Sola Kitchens gave this sleek modern black-and-white kitchen an organic feel with a large tree under the skylights to create a beguiling focal point. Continue to 88 of 93 below 88 of 93 Try a Pocket Pantry Door Credit: Marie Flanigan Interiors Save space and preserve flow with a pocket pantry door. Marie Flanigan Interiors chose a rustic wood arched door to add character to this kitchen, but you can opt for any style and shape that fits your space. Continue to 89 of 93 below 89 of 93 Add Decorative Beams Credit: Erin Williamson Design Give your kitchen a rustic feel with decorative wood ceiling beams. Erin Williamson Design paired darker beams with lighter wood flooring and cabinetry in this spacious eat-in kitchen. Continue to 90 of 93 below 90 of 93 Try Concrete Countertops Credit: Pluck Kitchens Concrete countertops will give your kitchen a modern feel or complement an industrial loft makeover. Pluck Kitchens covered the countertops, backsplash, and kitchen island in this kitchen for a streamlined feel. Continue to 91 of 93 below 91 of 93 Try a Coastal Kitchen Credit: Tyler Karu Design and Interiors Create a coastal kitchen with texture and warmth by mixing shades of blue and white with warm wood finishes. This kitchen from Tyler Karu Design and Interiors includes warm wood grain walls, deep blue zellige tiles, and pale cabinets and countertops for a relaxed feel. Continue to 92 of 93 below 92 of 93 Try Brick Tile Flooring Credit: Marie Flanigan Interiors Give your kitchen or pantry floors a rustic makeover with brick tile flooring. Marie Flanigan Interiors paired herringbone brick tile flooring with white cabinetry, dark wood countertops, and bronze hardware for a modern farmhouse meets traditional feel. Continue to 93 of 93 below 93 of 93 Embrace Chocolate Brown Credit: Ashley Montgomery Design Create a warm and enveloping feel in a traditional, farmhouse, or country-style kitchen with chocolate brown finishes. Ashley Montgomery Design mixed rich brown painted cabinetry with dark wood flooring and a dark brown stained wood backsplash in this homey kitchen. Explore more: Home Design & Decorating Room Design Kitchen Design
